articles.description: A Palestinian woman and her husband were arrested in Israel on terrorism charges over her WhatsApp status.
articles.title: Palestinians arrested for âterrorismâ over WhatsApp status

articles.description:
Senior UN officials said on Saturday said there could be no justification for any âacts of warâ in or around any healthcare facilities, amidst reports that Gazaâs largest hospital has come under attack by Israeli forces as they battle Palestinian militants.

Read the full story, âAttacks on or near Gaza hospitals âunconscionable, reprehensible and must stopâ: Relief chiefâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Attacks on or near Gaza hospitals âunconscionable, reprehensible and must stopâ: Relief chief

articles.description:
A political solution to end the cycle of conflict in Israel and Palestine has become a stark âmatter of life and deathâ for millions in Gaza and beyond, said the head of the UN relief agency for Palestine refugees (UNRWA) on Saturday.

Read the full story, ââGenuine prospect of Palestinian statehood is criticalâ, UNRWA chief tells emergency summit in Saudi Arabiaâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: âGenuine prospect of Palestinian statehood is criticalâ, UNRWA chief tells emergency summit in Saudi Arabia

articles.description:
SANTIAGO, Nov 10 (IPS) - Mario Lubetkin is FAO Assistant Director-General and FAO Regional Representative for Latin America and the CaribbeanThe figures published by the latest Regional Overview of Food Security and Nutrition 2023 are cause for great concern. The document is clear: hunger continues to significantly affect Latin America and the Caribbean.

Read the full story, âShared Responsibility: Eradicating Hunger in Latin America and the Caribbeanâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Shared Responsibility: Eradicating Hunger in Latin America and the Caribbean

articles.description:
NAIROBI, Nov 10 (IPS) - Somalia, Syria, DRC Congo, Afghanistan, Yemen, Chad, South Sudan, Central African Republic, Nigeria, and Ethiopia are the 10 countries at greatest risk of climate disaster globally despite collectively contributing just 0.28 percent of global CO2 emissions. A climate-induced humanitarian crisis continues to unfold across these countries and many others in the global South, including Kenya, which declared drought a national disaster in September 2021.

Read the full story, âCarbon Market Greenwashing Systems Deepen Inequalities in Global South - Expertsâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Carbon Market Greenwashing Systems Deepen Inequalities in Global South - Experts

articles.description:
KATHMANDU, Nov 10 (IPS) - Emergency health services are grappling with the enormous challenge of providing essential care to individuals affected by a deadly earthquake that claimed the lives of at least 153 and around 400 people wounded in western Nepal.

Read the full story, âHealthcare Crisis Follows Deadly Earthquake in Nepalâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Healthcare Crisis Follows Deadly Earthquake in Nepal

articles.description:
NEW DELHI, India, Nov 10 (IPS) - For a long time, the agriculture sector has been heralded as a success story for India. Spurred by the Green Revolution, it provided a path-breaking solution to feed the country's burgeoning population starting in the 1960s.

Read the full story, âRecognizing Food & Land-Use Systems as Contributors to Climate Changeâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Recognizing Food & Land-Use Systems as Contributors to Climate Change

articles.description:
The international community must act now to end the bloodshed and suffering in Gaza, scores of UN Ambassadors in Geneva said in a joint call on Friday.

Read the full story, â70 UN Ambassadors in Geneva call for international action on Gazaâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: 70 UN Ambassadors in Geneva call for international action on Gaza

articles.description:
The UN Security Council met again on Friday to discuss the ongoing Israel-Palestine crisis as negotiations continue behind the scenes within the 15 member body to reach some consensus position over the war raging in Gaza. Ambassadors heard searing testimony from the UN health agency chief who said the entire health system of the enclave was now "on its knees". Catch up with the full meeting via UN Web TV, here.

Read the full story, â'Nowhere and no one is safe' in Gaza, WHO chief tells Security Councilâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: 'Nowhere and no one is safe' in Gaza, WHO chief tells Security Council

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) has updated its guidelines on COVID-19 treatment, with revised recommendations for non-severe cases of the disease.

Read the full story, âUpdated guidelines on COVID-19 revise risk of hospitalisationâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Updated guidelines on COVID-19 revise risk of hospitalisation

articles.description:
Escalating violence across the Darfur region in Sudan has sparked fears that atrocities committed two decades ago could be repeated, the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, said on Friday, voicing grave concern over the development.

Read the full story, âSudan: UNHCR warns Darfur atrocities of 20 years ago may reoccurâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Sudan: UNHCR warns Darfur atrocities of 20 years ago may reoccur

articles.description:
Nearly 20 years of development progress could be wiped out in the Occupied Palestine Territories if the conflict between Israel and Hamas continues for a second full month, according to a UN report published on Thursday.

Read the full story, âGaza conflict could spark rise in poverty, UN agencies warnâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Gaza conflict could spark rise in poverty, UN agencies warn

articles.description:
The UN rights chief Volker TÃ¼rk reiterated increasingly urgent calls on Friday for a humanitarian ceasefire to allow lifesaving relief to reach Gaza, the release of all hostages taken from Israel and a âsustainableâ end to the ânightmarishâ situation for those trapped in the enclave.

Read the full story, âIsrael-Palestine crisis: Amid war crimes fears, UN rights chief renews calls to stop violence, free hostagesâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Israel-Palestine crisis: Amid war crimes fears, UN rights chief renews calls to stop violence, free hostages

articles.description:
SAN FRANCISCO, USA, Nov 09 (IPS) - The governments of Israel and the United States are now in disagreement over how many Palestinian civilians itâs okay to kill. Last week -- as the death toll from massive Israeli bombardment of Gaza neared 10,000 people, including several thousand children -- top U.S. officials began to worry about the rising horrified outcry at home and abroad. So, they went public with muted misgivings and calls for a âhumanitarian pause.â But Israelâs Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made clear that he would have none of it.

Read the full story, âIsraels Military Is Part of the U.S. War Machineâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Israels Military Is Part of the U.S. War Machine

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Nov 09 (IPS) - The killings of thousands of civilians in the ongoing Middle East conflict are largely the result of an uneven battleâa nuclear-armed Israel, equipped with some of the most sophisticated American weapons systems, fighting a rag-tag militant group, Hamas.

Read the full story, âArms Suppliers to Israel & Hamas Should Face War Crime ChargesBut Will They?â, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Arms Suppliers to Israel & Hamas Should Face War Crime ChargesBut Will They?

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
OPINION / EXPERT PERSPECTIVE â This is the twentieth anniversary of the Six Party Talks, established in 2003, to resolve the nuclear issue with North [...] More 
The post A Nuclear North Korea Presents Opportunity for Global Leadership in a Complicated World appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: A Nuclear North Korea Presents Opportunity for Global Leadership in a Complicated World

Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: Middle East News: GAZA STRIP: Palestinians seeking refuge at Gaza's largest hospital and staff said they were trapped in increasingly horrific conditions Saturday, with.
articles.title: Heavy fighting spurs 'catastrophic' scene at Gaza hospital

articles.description: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has condemned the violent clashes that occurred during a pro-Palestinian march in London. Far-right protesters clashed with police during a counter-demonstration that coincided with Armistice Day. Sunak stated that the actions of the far-right groups disrespect the armed forces and expressed concern for the fear and intimidation experienced by the Jewish community.
articles.title: UK Prime Minister condemns violence around pro-Palestinian march

articles.description: President Joe Biden visited Arlington National Cemetery on Veterans Day to honor America's veterans. He spoke about the sacrifices made by U.S. troops in famous battles and emphasized the importance of their oath to defend the United States. The day holds personal significance for Biden as his son, Beau, served in the military and later passed away from brain cancer.
articles.title: Biden says America's veterans are 'the steel spine of this nation' as he pays tribute at Arlington

articles.description: An investigation by The Washington Post and German outlet Der Spiegel suggests that a Ukrainian special forces commander, Roman Chervinsky, played a key role in the sabotage of the Nord Stream gas pipelines in September 2020. Chervinsky allegedly oversaw logistics and support for a team that placed explosive charges on the pipelines, causing damage and cutting off a major route for Russian gas exports to Europe. Chervinsky denies any involvement, stating that the claims are spread by Russian propaganda.
articles.title: Ukraine officer had key role in Nord Stream sabotage: Reports

articles.description: Several thousand people gathered in Paris to protest the ongoing conflict in Gaza and called for an immediate ceasefire between Israel and Hamas. Similar rallies took place in other French cities as well. The Israeli military campaign in response to Hamas's attack has resulted in a significant number of casualties in Gaza. French MPs from the hard-left France Unbowed party were present at the march. The organizers emphasized the importance of mobilization against these massacres.
articles.title: Paris protesters call for Gaza ceasefire

articles.description: Young people in Rio de Janeiro planted tree seedlings to create a safe passageway for the endangered golden lion tamarin. The initiative aims to connect patches of forest that have been destroyed by deforestation. The Atlantic Forest, where the tamarin is found, has been reduced to just 2% of its original size. Efforts to save the species have been successful, with the population now at around 4,800 individuals. However, maintaining and expanding the habitat requires significant resources.
articles.title: Saving Brazil's golden monkey, one green corridor at a time

articles.description: Hezbollah's leader, Hassan Nasrallah, announced that the group is using new weapons in its attacks against Israel. This comes as exchanges of fire on Lebanon's southern border intensify. Nasrallah mentioned that Hezbollah is using "Burkan missiles" for the first time, which can carry a payload of 300-500 kilograms. The group is also using attack drones and reconnaissance drones to target Israel. Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant warned that Lebanese citizens would "pay the price" for Hezbollah's actions.
articles.title: Lebanon's Hezbollah bolsters attacks on Israel with new weapons: Chief

articles.description: Mexico's ruling party, Morena, has named its candidates for eight governorships and the mayorship of Mexico City. The party's decision to exclude the most popular candidate for the capital has raised concerns about potential desertions. Former capital police chief Omar Garcia Harfuch, who was disqualified due to a gender quota, has expressed his loyalty to the party. Morena has already announced its nominee for the presidential race, former Mexico City mayor Claudia Sheinbaum.
articles.title: Mexico''s ruling party names gubernatorial candidates, but questions remain about unity

articles.description: About 21,000 people took part in a pro-Palestinian rally in Brussels on Saturday, police said, many chanting slogans such as "Free Palestine" and demanding a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip as they marched peacefully through the city. "What is happening right now in Gaza is beyond devastating," one demonstrator said, carrying a poster that read "Ceasefire now!" in Dutch. Other protesters held up posters that read "Stop the Genocide", "Human Rights for Palestinians" or demanded the arrest of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over what they called war crimes.
articles.title: More than 20,000 people join pro-Palestinian rally in Brussels

articles.description: An investigation reveals that SpaceX CEO Elon Musk's dislike for bright colors has compromised worker safety. Musk reportedly asked employees not to wear safety vests and failed to separate dangerous areas from workspaces. The investigation also found that over 600 workers have been injured since 2014. Safety measures, such as tie-downs for transporting cargo, were lacking, leading to incidents like the death of an employee.
articles.title: Elon Muskâs dislike for bright colors raises SpaceX workplace safety concerns: Report

articles.description: A military jet fighter crashed in Myanmar's eastern state of Kayah, with conflicting reports on whether it was shot down or crashed due to technical failure. The ethnic armed group, the Karenni Nationalities Defense Force, claimed responsibility for shooting down the plane during heavy fighting near Loikaw, the capital of Kayah state. Myanmar has seen the rise of resistance groups since the military seized power in February 2021. The conflict has driven thousands of people from their homes.
articles.title: Military jet crashes in eastern Myanmar; Ethnic resistance groups claim they shot it down

articles.description: Russian authorities said Saturday they had launched a "terrorism" probe after the derailment of a goods train southwest of Moscow. An "improvised explosive device" caused the derailment of 19 of the train's wagons in the Riazan region on Saturday, the state investigation committee said in a social media announcement. Several sabotage attempts have been made on Russian railways since the country started its offensive against Ukraine in February 2022.
articles.title: Russia opens 'terrorism' inquiry over train derailment

articles.description: Members of the "Saturday Mothers" group, consisting of relatives of victims of enforced disappearances in Turkey, held a vigil in Istanbul without police intervention for the first time since 2018. The group's protest, which seeks justice for missing persons and punishment for the perpetrators, has been met with bans, dispersals, and arrests by the police in the past. However, the Constitutional Court recently ruled that the group's right to organize demonstrations had been violated.
articles.title: Turkey allows decades-old mothers' vigil after five-year ban

articles.description: Tens of thousands of people are expected to march in Paris against anti-Semitism amid a surge in anti-Semitic incidents in France. More than 3,000 police and gendarmes will be deployed to ensure security. President Emmanuel Macron expressed his support for the march, and leaders from the National Assembly and Senate have called for a "general mobilisation" against anti-Semitism. However, the far-left France Unbowed party will boycott the event, and the far-right National Rally plans to attend.
articles.title: Thousands to march in France against anti-Semitism

articles.description: Mexico's ruling party, the National Regeneration Movement (MORENA), has chosen Clara Brugada as its candidate for Mexico City mayor. Brugada, a two-time congresswoman and former mayor of Iztapalapa, will run for the position in the June election. If successful, she will become the second woman in a row to be elected as mayor of the Mexican capital. New gender parity rules on political representation secured Brugada's nomination, despite losing in polling commissioned by the party.
articles.title: Mexico's ruling party again picks woman to run for mayor of capital

articles.description: Hezbollah's leader, Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, announced that his group has used new weapons and targeted new locations in Israel. He stated that there has been an increase in the number and size of operations, as well as the type of weapons used. Nasrallah confirmed the use of weaponized drones and a missile called the Burkan. He also mentioned that Hezbollah had struck the Israeli town of Kiryat Shmona for the first time. Nasrallah pledged that the front against Israel would remain active.
articles.title: Hezbollah says front with Israel will remain active

articles.description: A study led by scientists at the University of Gothenburg has found hundreds of harmful compounds, including pesticides and medications, in pellets made from recycled plastic. The study concludes that recycled plastics are unfit for most purposes and hinder efforts to create a circular economy. The researchers urge delegates at an upcoming meeting in Nairobi to consider the latest science.
articles.title: Scientists discover hundreds of hazardous compounds in recycled plastics

articles.description: A suspect who was in custody in the investigation of the fatal stabbing of a Detroit synagogue leader has been released, a lawyer said Saturday. Allison Kriger declined to comment further to The Associated Press beyond saying the suspect was free. The Detroit Free Press said the suspect was a man. No charges have been filed in the case. Samantha Woll, 40, was president of Isaac Agree Downtown Synagogue. She was found dead outside her Detroit home October 21, hours after returning from a wedding, though investigators believe the attack occurred inside.
articles.title: Suspect released in fatal stabbing of Detroit synagogue leader

articles.description: A pro-Palestinian march took place in London, drawing hundreds of thousands of people. Counter-protests by right-wing groups also occurred. The Metropolitan Police faced aggression from the counter-protesters but vowed to prevent clashes between the two groups. The march was held on Armistice Day, which led to criticism from government ministers. The rally was organized by the Palestine Solidarity Campaign and was expected to be peaceful.
articles.title: London police scuffle with far-right protesters as pro-Palestinian rally starts

articles.description: Former President Donald Trump is pushing for his federal election interference trial in Washington to be televised, despite opposition from the Justice Department. Media outlets argue that the American public should be able to watch the historic case unfold. Trump's lawyers argue that the trial should be televised so that the public can see that the case is a politically motivated charade. Trump was indicted on felony charges in August for attempting to overturn the 2020 election results.
articles.title: Donald Trump joins media outlets in pushing for his federal election interference case to be televised

articles.description: Nearly 2,000 police officers will be on duty in London as over 100,000 pro-Palestinian supporters are expected to march through the city on Saturday. The march coincides with Armistice Day, leading to concerns about potential clashes. Metal barriers will be placed around landmark memorials, and police will be able to arrest marchers attempting to gather there. Right-wing counter-protesters, including football hooligans, are also expected to be present. The event has caused a rift between the police and government, with calls to ban the march leading to accusations of political interference.
articles.title: UK police out in force for 'tense' pro-Palestinian march

articles.description: Israeli air strikes hit three Gaza hospitals and a school on Friday, killing at least 22 people. Palestinian officials reported that a ground battle was also taking place at another hospital. The Israeli military claims that the hospitals are being used by Hamas militants as human shields, a claim that Hamas denies. Gaza's hospitals were already struggling to cope with the conflict, with shortages of medical supplies, clean water, and fuel. Thousands of people have been forced to flee in the wake of the attacks.
articles.title: Gaza hospitals in firing line that Israel claims are militant hubs

articles.description: Nearly half of Democrats disapprove of how President Joe Biden is handling the Israel-Hamas conflict, according to a new poll from The Associated Press-NORC Centre for Public Affairs Research - showing a deep divide within his party over the war. The poll found 50% of Democrats approve of how Biden has navigated the conflict while 46% disapprove.  Biden's support on the issue among Democrats is down slightly from August.
articles.title: Disapproval of Biden's response to Gaza war rising among Dems: Poll

articles.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken expressed concern over the high number of Palestinian casualties in Gaza due to Israel's bombardment and ground invasion. While acknowledging some positive steps taken by Israel to improve conditions in Gaza, Blinken emphasized that more needs to be done to protect civilians and ensure the delivery of humanitarian aid. He also mentioned ongoing discussions with Israel to secure the release of hostages held by Palestinian militants.
articles.title: Blinken says far too many Palestinians have been killed

articles.description: Saudi Arabia's de facto ruler on Friday denounced the conduct of Israeli forces fighting Hamas in Gaza, ahead of weekend summits that will focus on the unfolding violence in the Palestinian territory. "We condemn the military aggression witnessed in the Gaza Strip, the targeting of civilians, and the continued violations of international humanitarian law by the Israeli occupation forces," Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman told a summit with African leaders, his first public comments on the Israel-Hamas war.
articles.title: In first comments on war, Saudi Arabia's Mohammed Bin Salman slams Israel 'aggression'

articles.description: The US FDA has approved the world's first vaccine for chikungunya, a virus transmitted by infected mosquitoes. The vaccine, developed by Valneva, will be marketed as Ixchiq and is approved for individuals aged 18 and over at increased risk of exposure. Chikungunya, which causes fever and severe joint pain, is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions. The vaccine contains a weakened version of the virus and has shown some common side effects such as headache and fatigue.
articles.title: US approves world's 1st chikungunya vaccine

articles.description: House Republicans and some Democrats have censured Democrat representative Rashida Tlaib for her support of the pro-Palestinian slogan "from the river to the sea", which they consider a "genocidal call to violence". The White House has disavowed the phrase, calling it divisive and hurtful. Tlaib defends the phrase as a call for freedom and peaceful coexistence. The slogan dates back to the Palestinian nationalist movement in the 1960s and has different interpretations among Israelis, Palestinians, and Americans who support them.
articles.title: Across America, 'from the river to the sea' inflames debate

articles.description: Frank Borman, the astronaut who commanded Apollo 8's historic flight around the moon in 1968, has died at the age of 95. Borman, along with his crewmates James Lovell and William Anders, became the first humans to orbit the moon and see Earth from space. The mission was a significant milestone in the lead-up to the lunar landing the following year. Borman later led Eastern Airlines and was remembered as a true American hero by NASA administrator Bill Nelson.
articles.title: Frank Borman, astronaut who led first orbit of the moon, dies at 95

articles.description: The UN warned Friday of soaring human rights violations in Sudan's Darfur region and said they were "verging on pure evil," amid escalating fighting seven months into the war between the army and paramilitaries. "We keep saying that the situation is horrific and grim. But frankly, we are running out of words to describe the horror of what is happening in Sudan," said Clementine Nkweta-Salami, the UN humanitarian coordinator for Sudan. "What is happening is verging on pure evil," she said.
articles.title: Sudan violence 'verging on pure evil,' UN warns

articles.description: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has called for the protection of medical facilities and workers in Gaza, stating that the healthcare system there has reached a point of no return. The ICRC has distributed critical supplies to medical structures in Gaza and has witnessed the worsening conditions due to intensified hostilities. Hospitals and ambulances are being severely affected, leading to a heavy toll on civilians, patients, and medical staff.
articles.title: Gaza health system has reached 'point of no return': Red Cross

articles.description: France has expelled a Palestinian activist, Mariam Abu Daqqa, to Egypt after a court battle. Abu Daqqa, a leading member of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), had a 50-day visa to visit France for conferences on the Middle East conflict. However, the interior ministry deemed her presence a risk following the October 7 Hamas attacks against Israel. Abu Daqqa criticized her expulsion as an attack on Palestine's right to have a state.
articles.title: France expels Palestinian activist to Egypt

articles.description: A federal judge has denied Donald Trump's request to delay the start of the trial in the special counsel's classified documents case. The judge kept open the option of rescheduling during a conference on March 1. Trump wanted a postponement due to ongoing civil and criminal cases in New York, Florida, and Washington, DC. The judge acknowledged the high volume of discovery and access challenges, supporting the defense's argument for more time.
articles.title: Judge rejects Trump's request to delay May trial date in classified documents case

articles.description: A person facing terrorism charges in Brazil revealed to the Federal Police that they traveled to Beirut in April to meet with a suspected Hezbollah leader recruiting individuals for violent activities. The testimony, seen by Reuters, also mentioned the suspect's belief that the organization engaged in "not clean activity." Brazil recently arrested two individuals suspected of planning attacks on Jewish targets, with Israel's Mossad spy agency assisting in foiling the plot. The suspect's statement to police, heavily redacted, did not include their name or other crucial details.
articles.title: Brazil suspect in Hezbollah bust says was recruited 'to kill and kidnap'

articles.description: A federal judge in Florida has refused to delay Donald Trump's classified documents trial, stating that the defence's request was premature. The trial is currently scheduled to begin on May 20, 2024. Trump's lawyers argued that they needed more time to review the extensive evidence and cited scheduling challenges due to other legal cases against Trump. The judge pushed back some deadlines but maintained the trial date. Trump is also facing federal charges in Washington, state charges in New York, and a business fraud case in New York.
articles.title: Judge declines for now to push back Trump's classified documents trial but postpones other deadlines

articles.description: A24 production company has won the rights to adapt the biography of Elon Musk into a film, with director Darren Aronofsky attached to the project. The book, written by Walter Isaacson, explores Musk's childhood, his drive to bring human life to Mars, and his demanding nature as a leader. The biography also delves into Musk's relationship with his abusive father and his impulsive behavior on social media. No timeline for the film's development or release has been announced.
articles.title: Bestseller Musk biography to be adapted into film

articles.description: Evacuations from the Gaza Strip into Egypt for foreign passport holders and for Palestinians needing urgent medical treatment were suspended on Friday, three Egyptian security sources and a Palestinian official said. The Palestinian official and an Egyptian medical source said the suspension was due to problems bringing medical evacuees to the Rafah border crossing from inside Gaza. Limited evacuations from Gaza to Egypt began on Nov. 1 and were paused twice in the past week due to bombardments that aid staff said hit or targeted medical convoys.
articles.title: Evacuations from Gaza to Egypt suspended on Friday

articles.description: Spain's acting Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has secured the backing of two more regional parties, the National Basque Party and the Canaries' Coalition, giving him an absolute majority in the lower house. However, this support comes amid controversy over Sanchez's pledge of amnesty for Catalan separatists. The deal with Junts, a Catalan separatist party, includes passing a contentious law granting amnesty to those convicted over Catalonia's attempt to secede from Spain in 2017.
articles.title: Spain's Sanchez wins support for PM bid amid anger over Catalan amnesty vow

articles.description: The parents of a critically ill British baby girl have lost their legal bid to have her life support removed at home. Eight-month-old Indi Gregory suffers from a rare mitochondrial disease and has been on full life support since September. Her doctors say she suffers from significant pain and distress and there is no point in continuing treatment. The UK Court of Appeal dismissed the parents' challenge, ruling that her treatment should be removed either in hospital or at a hospice.
articles.title: UK court rejects appeal over where critically ill baby's treatment ends

articles.description: A man was arrested for allegedly assaulting former US senator Martha McSally as she jogged along the Missouri River in Council Bluffs, Iowa. McSally fought off the attacker and chased him, but he managed to escape. However, video surveillance and investigative work led to his identification and subsequent arrest. McSally, who had previously disclosed being raped by a superior officer in the Air Force, stated that the assault tapped into past experiences of sexual abuse and assault.
articles.title: Man arrested in Nebraska in alleged assault of former US senator Martha McSally

articles.description: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has called for the protection of medical facilities and workers in Gaza, stating that the healthcare system there has reached a point of no return. The ICRC has distributed critical supplies to medical structures in Gaza and has witnessed the worsening conditions due to intensified hostilities. Hospitals and ambulances are being severely affected, leading to a heavy toll on civilians, patients, and medical staff.
articles.title: Gaza health system has reached 'point of no return': Red Cross

articles.description: US News: WASHINGTON: US health authorites on Thursday approved the world's first vaccine for chikungunya, a virus spread by infected mosquitoes.
articles.title: US approves first vaccine against chikungunya virus

articles.description: Jarrett Garrett McCabe, a man with a history of violent crimes including murder, was arrested for assaulting a teenager at his son's bus stop in Florida. McCabe had learned that his son had been involved in altercations with the teenager in the past. Instead of waiting for the situation to resolve itself, McCabe confronted the boys as soon as they got off the bus.
articles.title: Florida man, previously convicted of murder, arrested for punching teen at bus stop

articles.description: Surgeons at NYU Langone Health in New York have successfully performed the world's first complete human eye transplant on a patient named Aaron James. The procedure, which took place in May, aims to enhance the overall cosmetic outcome by providing support to the transplanted eye socket and lid. While the patient's vision outcome remains uncertain, the transplanted eye appears healthy, marking a significant advancement in the field of medical innovation. This surgery provides scientists with an extraordinary opportunity to study and understand the healing process of the human eye.
articles.title: New York surgeons perform world's first human eyeball transplant

articles.description: Steve Bannon, former senior adviser to Donald Trump, appealed his criminal conviction for defying a subpoena from a congressional panel investigating the Capitol attack. Bannon argued that he did not receive a fair trial because the judge barred him from making arguments central to his defense, including his claim that he did not have to comply with the subpoena due to executive privilege. However, the appeals court appeared skeptical of his argument, noting that much of the information sought by the committee was unrelated to his interactions with Trump.
articles.title: Donald Trump ally Steve Bannon faces skeptical court in bid to overturn contempt conviction

articles.description: Two 18-year-olds, Charlotte Wimer and Gray Segal, were arrested in New York for tearing down posters depicting Israeli hostages kidnapped by Hamas. The incident took place outside a private property in Gramercy Park. The two individuals have been charged with criminal mischief. The torn-down posters have been replaced with new ones, featuring images of the 240 hostages taken by the terror group. This act of vandalizing or removing the posters has been condemned as antisemitic and inhumane.
articles.title: Two 18-year-olds arrested after tearing down Hamas hostages posters in New York

articles.description: Seven detectives from the Nashville police department have been suspended after writings by a killer were leaked online. The detectives have been placed on administrative assignment to investigate how conservative commentator Steven Crowder obtained the documents. The move is said to be to protect the integrity of the ongoing investigation and is not punitive.
articles.title: US: Nashville police suspends 7 detectives after school shooter's writings leaked

articles.author: Raj Shekhar
articles.description: A top Lashkar-e-Taiba commander, Akram Ghazi, was shot dead in Pakistan, making it the second assassination of a terrorist targeting India in one week. Ghazi was responsible for recruiting terrorists for Lashkar and played a role in radicalizing individuals who infiltrated into Kashmir. Pakistani agencies are investigating the killing and are considering local rivals and internal conflicts within Lashkar as possible motives. This killing adds to a series of recent setbacks for Lashkar and its parent organization, ISI.
articles.title: Key LeT commander killed by unidentified men in Pakistan

articles.description: Violence and fighting have escalated in Sudan, particularly in the capital and in the western region of Darfur. Witnesses report seeing corpses in the streets, and there are concerns about ethnically motivated mass killings. The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Sudanese army are battling for control, with the RSF claiming control of all but one major city in Darfur. There have been reports of serious human rights abuses by the RSF and affiliated militias, and the US embassy in Khartoum has expressed deep concern.
articles.title: Bodies litter streets as fighting intensifies in Sudan

articles.description: Greece's state ombudsman is launching an independent investigation into the coast guard's handling of a maritime tragedy in June. The incident involved an overloaded boat carrying migrants trying to reach Europe, with hundreds feared to have drowned. The ombudsman's decision comes after the Greek coast guard denied initiating a disciplinary investigation. A military court is already conducting a preliminary investigation into the shipwreck, which resulted in 104 survivors and 78 bodies being recovered.
articles.title: Independent inquiry launched into shipwreck off Greece that left hundreds of migrants feared dead

articles.description: US stock markets remained steady as investors awaited signals from the Federal Reserve regarding US interest rates. European indices, on the other hand, closed the day with solid gains. Oil prices rebounded slightly but had minimal impact on the recent losses due to slowing demand expectations and reduced fears of a broader conflict in the Middle East.
articles.title: US stocks pause for breath as traders await Fed guidance

articles.description: Israel has agreed to implement four-hour daily humanitarian pauses in its offensive against Hamas in northern Gaza, according to the White House. President Joe Biden had urged Israel for a multi-day stoppage in the fighting to secure the release of hostages held by Hamas. While a formal cease-fire is not currently possible, Biden requested a pause of at least three days for negotiations. Israel will also open a second corridor for civilians to flee the conflict areas.
articles.title: Israel agrees to 4-hour daily pauses in Gaza fighting to allow civilians to flee, White House says

articles.description: The shortage of lamination paper in Pakistan is causing delays in issuing new passports, leading to difficulties for citizens. The paper used for passports is imported from France, and the limited supply is causing a backlog in processing applications. Many individuals, including students and those planning to travel for work or leisure, are being affected by the delays. The government has assured that the situation will soon be under control, but there is skepticism among the public.
articles.title: Pakistan running out of lamination paper, unable to print passports

articles.description: Germany commemorated the 85th anniversary of Kristallnacht, or the "Night of Broken Glass," in which the Nazis terrorized Jews throughout the country. Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Jewish leader Josef Schuster spoke at an anniversary ceremony in Berlin and condemned the discrimination and antisemitism that still exists in Germany. The commemoration comes at a time when antisemitism is on the rise in Germany and across Europe, with many Jews living in fear and facing discrimination.
articles.title: Germans commemorate 'Night of Broken Glass' terror as antisemitism is on the rise again

articles.description: Spanish right-wing politician Alejandro Vidal-Quadras has been shot in the face on a street in Madrid. The 78-year-old, a former member of Spain's conservative Popular Party and a founder of the far-right Vox party, was conscious when taken to the hospital. Police are investigating the shooting, and no arrests have been made. Vox President Santiago Abascal stated that Vidal-Quadras' life is not in immediate danger.
articles.title: Spanish conservative politician shot in face in Madrid. Gunman escaped on a motorbike, reports

articles.description: CIA Director Bill Burns and David Barnea, who heads Israel's Mossad spy agency, are currently in Doha for trilateral discussions with Qatari officials. The talks aim to formulate a plan for a potential humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza, which would involve the release of hostages and the distribution of additional aid to the region.
articles.title: Israeli, US spy chiefs in Doha talks on Gaza humanitarian pause: official

articles.description: Russia has expressed shock at the Israeli ambassador's statement that it could take up to two weeks to evacuate Russian citizens from the Gaza Strip. The Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman called the logic unacceptable and stated that Russia had followed all the necessary procedures for submitting evacuation lists. Over 500 Russian citizens, including 300 minors, are waiting to be evacuated from the blockade in Gaza. No Russians have been confirmed as having left Gaza since the reopening of the Rafah checkpoint on November 1.
articles.title: Moscow 'shocked' by timeline to evacuate Russians from Gaza

articles.description: Israel's army is using data from carrion-eating birds to locate corpses from the October 7 attack by Hamas militants. Eagles, vultures, and other birds of prey fitted with tracking devices have been assisting in the search for human remains. The birds are part of a program that tracks their migratory patterns, feeding habits, and environmental threats.
articles.title: Birds of prey help Israel search for Hamas attack victims

articles.description: A banner asking residents to clean up after Diwali celebrations in Singapore will be taken down to avoid misunderstanding, according to a parliamentarian. The banner was put up by the Mountbatten Residents' Network to address the issue of litter left behind after the festival. However, it was misconstrued as targeting a particular race. Another banner with a festive message will remain.
articles.title: Lawmaker intervenes after banner asked Indians to clean up rubbish after Diwali celebrations in Singapore

articles.description: During a UN review of Germany's human rights record, several Muslim countries criticized Germany's support for Israel and its bans on pro-Palestinian protests. However, Germany received overall praise for its robust human rights record. The war in Gaza was a major point of contention, with countries like Egypt, Jordan, and Turkey criticizing Germany's position. Germany reiterated Israel's right to defend itself and expressed concern over rising anti-Semitic acts.
articles.title: Germany criticised at UN over Gaza war stance

articles.description: The heads of the CIA and Mossad met with the Qatari prime minister in Doha to discuss a potential deal for hostage releases and a temporary ceasefire between Hamas and Israel in Gaza. Qatar has been leading mediation efforts between the two sides. The outcome of the meeting is unknown. The talks also included discussions on allowing humanitarian fuel imports into Gaza. Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani later traveled to the UAE, where he met with the Emirati president, though the purpose of the visit is unclear.
articles.title: Mossad, CIA chiefs meet Qatar PM in Doha on Gaza hostage deal: Source

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish governmentâs earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response â waiting for aid and rescue teams â but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the disâ¦
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkeyâs bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy â and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russiaâs nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. âNearly every commerciaâ¦
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syriaâs deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. âIt was like the apocalypse,â Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last weekâs earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an uâ¦
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.Â  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOsâ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloonâs threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a âSputnik moment,â harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even warâ¦
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.author: David McAfee
articles.description:
Michael Cohen, known best as Donald Trump's former attorney and "fixer" who turned into a critic of the former president, made news on Saturday for his actions in confronting a woman who was taking down posters of hostages of Hamas.
Cohen, who made a splash at the ex-president's civil fraud trial, was reportedly walking around in New York when he saw the woman taking down the posters and even laughing.
Cohen started by asking what was wrong with the woman, according to the New York Post.
"Former Trump attorney Michael Cohen confronted a woman on the Upper East Side Friday tearing down fliers of missing Israeli hostages â precipitating a tense confrontation," the outlet reported Saturday.
"'Whatâs wrong with you?' Cohen snapped at the well-dressed middle-aged woman, wearing sunglasses and a beige trench coat and holding a tote bag, shows video obtained by The Post," the Post wrote. "This is illegal. Turn it on yourself, freak. You should be in jail,â the woman shot back, according to the news report.
The woman appeared to be confused about who Cohen was, according to the Post's account.
"She also appeared to confuse him with hedge fund billionaire and Mets owner Steve Cohen," it reported. "When Michael Cohen demanded the womanâs name, she said it was 'Steve Cohen and I should be back in jail because Iâm a piece of sât.'"
Cohen himself had this to say about the encounter:
"When reached by The Post, Michael Cohen said he wanted to get the womanâs name and hold her accountable," according to the Post's report. "While walking on Park Avenue at the corner of 61st street, I was shocked to see this racist, antisemitic curmudgeon tearing the face off the missing-child poster and laughing about it. There is no place for people like her in civilized society,â he said.
Read it here.
articles.title: 'What's wrong with you?' Michael Cohen confronts woman tearing down Hamas hostage posters

articles.author: David McAfee
articles.description:
Donald Trump on Saturday thanked the veterans attending his New Hampshire rally, but then proceeded to attack a familiar target: General Milley.
Trump veered off course from his stump speech several times at his rally, even appearing to confuse Barack Obama for Joe Biden at one point. He also took numerous shots at the retired general named Mark Milley, who said he had to restrain the former president's worst impulses throughout his time in office.
Trump mentioned Milley alongside secretary of defense James Mattis.
"You know Mattis. General Mattis. General Milley. Real beauties," Trump said on stage on Saturday.
"General Milley is the one who decided to take the soldiers out first," he added. "General Milley is the one that said let's leave $85 billion worth of equipment behind because it's cheaper than taking it out. It's cheaper than putting a tank of nice, clean fuel in the airplane and flying it to Pakistan or flying it all the way home. It's cheaper to leave it there."
He claimed 700,000 rifles, 70,000 vehicles, and more were left behind after war.
The ex-president added, "We have an unbelievable military. We just have some really bad leaders."
articles.title: 'Really bad leaders': Trump takes shots at retired general in Veteran's Day speech

articles.description:
Germany is increasing its humanitarian aid for the Palestinian Territories by a further â¬38 million ($40.7 million) in light of the suffering of the civilian population in the Gaza Strip as the Israel-Hamas war rages on.
Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock made the announcement on Saturday during her continuing diplomatic tour of the Middle East after talks with Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh in Ramallah in the West Bank. Germany will thus provide a total of over â¬160 million for the Palestinian Territories this year.
articles.title: Germany increases humanitarian aid to Palestinians by â¬38 million

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Pope Francis on Saturday dismissed US bishop Joseph Strickland, a prominent conservative who has repeatedly criticized his papacy, the Vatican announced.
The rare decision to remove a senior Catholic figure came after Francis sent two US bishops to visit Strickland's Texas diocese in June.
"The Holy Father has relieved from the pastoral governance of the diocese of Tyler (US) Joseph E. Strickland," the Vatican said in a statement.
It said the bishop of Austin, Joe Vasquez, had been named as apostolic administrator of the diocese, but gave no further details.
The Vatican has not said what sparked the apostolic visitation this summer -- which Strickland himself made public -- or what conclusions were drawn.
But Strickland, appointed by former pope Benedict XVI in 2012, was one of the most prominent critics of Pope Francis.
The Argentine pope, 86, has sought to forge a more compassionate Church, open to different views.
But he has faced intense opposition from critics -- particularly in the United States -- who accused him of causing confusion and failing to uphold key Catholic beliefs.
In a message earlier this year on X, formerly Twitter, Strickland accused the pope of "undermining the deposit of faith".
In a blog posted on his website in September, the bishop addressed rumours that he was being encouraged by the Vatican to step down.
"I cannot resign as bishop of Tyler because that would be me abandoning the flock" under his care, he wrote.
"I have also said that I will respect the authority of Pope Francis if he removes me from office as Bishop of Tyler," he wrote.
"I love Jesus Christ and the Catholic Church which He established. My only desire is to speak His Truth and live God's Will to the best of my ability," he wrote.
The diocese of Tyler on Saturday announced the Vatican's decision to dismiss the bishop on its website, saying: "Our work as the Catholic Church in northeast Texas continues."
Â© 2023 AFP
articles.title: Pope dismisses U.S. bishop who was prominent critic

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
LGBTQ rights campaigners welcomed a Vatican statement that transgender people can be baptized as a step towards a more inclusive Catholic Church, but denounced caveats that provide cover to those who object.
In a document published on Wednesday, the powerful Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith, one of the main departments that manages the affairs of the Holy See, said transgender believers can be baptized if it would not cause scandal or confusion.

The document, written in response to questions from a Brazilian bishop and approved by Pope Francis, also raised no objections to baptism for the children of same-sex couples, either adopted or born through surrogacy.
In reality, such baptisms already occur in different dioceses around the world.
But by putting it in black and white, the Vaâ¦
articles.title: Vatican takes 'step' toward transgender Catholics

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Fans of "The Crown" are holding their breath for the final season of the hit Netflix drama about the life of Queen Elizabeth II, with the last episodes covering some of the most tumultuous times of the monarchy.
The 10 episodes of the sixth and final season of the series is being released in two stages, with five episodes on Thursday, and the remainder on December 14.
The series notably features the event that shook the British monarchy to its core -- the death of Princess Diana on August 31, 1997.
- The people's princess -
A trailer for the new season, which will recount the last weeks of Diana's life after her tumultuous divorce from the current King Charles III up to her death, shows the princess (Elizabeth Debicki) overwhelmed by media attention.
"You have finally managed to turn everyâ¦
articles.title: 'The Crown' set for final season

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Russia has been spreading "disinformation" about the situation in the Middle East, the president of Microsoft said Saturday, as tensions soar in the region due to the Israel-Hamas war.
Brad Smith, Microsoft vice chair and president, was asked about the role of the US tech giant in promoting peace at an international peace forum in Paris.
He said that Microsoft and its competitors were fighting against disinformation, in particular by using Artificial Intelligence (AI).
Smith said that Microsoft and other companies are doing this "by creating technological tools that facilitate the detection of manipulated, modified, altered content," according to remarks translated in French by radio France Inter.
"We are getting very good at identifying a Russian campaign, like when they tried to tell people not to get the Covid vaccine," he said.
"Or today, when we see Russian disinformation in the Middle East," he added.
He said the three options facing technology platforms that identify this kind of disinformation are to do nothing, delete it, or re-label it and flag the content has been modified.
"There is no societal consensus about what companies should do," Smith added.
Th Paris Peace Forum opened against a backdrop of proliferating conflict around the world, and more than a month into the war between Israel and Hamas in the Gaza Strip.
Since Hamas attacks in southern Israel on October 7 -- in which Israel says 1,200 people were killed and 239 taken hostage -- Israel has bombarded Gaza relentlessly and sent in ground troops.
The Palestinian territory's Hamas-run health ministry says more than 11,000 people have been killed in Gaza, many of them children.
In an interview with the BBC on the fringes of the peace forum on Friday, French President Emmanuel Macron condemend the Hamas attacks but called on Israel to stop bombing civilians in Gaza, saying there was "no justification" and the deaths were causing "resentment".
articles.title: Microsoft chief says Russia is spreading Middle East disinformation

He did not provide a reason for the revision. The death count, which includes foreigners, "is not a final number. It (is) an updated estimate. It might change when (they) identify all the bod...
articles.title: Israel revises Hamas attack death toll to 'around 1,200'

articles.author: Sky Palma
articles.description:
A Jewish woman was attacked after she confronted two other women who were tearing down posters of Israelis who were kidnapped by Hamas, The New York Post reported. 
According to the NYPD, the 41-year-old victim âengaged the two females in a verbal disputeâ as she recorded the incident on her cellphone. 
The suspects then ripped the victim's Star of David necklace from her neck and knocked her cellphone out of her hand before fleeing on foot, leaving her with minor injuries to her face and neck. 
The NYPD released pictures of the two suspects, one of whom can be seen wearing a nose ring. 
Pro-Palestinian protesters have been captured on video in multiple incidents around New York City where they can be seen tearing down posters of kidnapped Israelis. 
At least 1,400 people, most of them civilians, were killed by Hamas on Oct. 7 in the worst terror attack in Israel's history.
articles.title: Women caught tearing down posters of kidnapped Israelis sought in attack on Jewish woman

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The publishers of two UK newspapers on Friday lost a bid to have a case for unlawful information gathering brought against them by Prince Harry and others thrown out of court, opening the way for a possible trial.
Lawyers for Associated Newspapers (ANL) -- publishers of the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday -- had argued that the claims were brought too late.
But in a written ruling, judge Matthew Nicklin disagreed and said the case could go ahead.
The ruling is the latest chapter in Harry's turbulent relationship with the press, whom he holds responsible for the death of his mother Princess Diana in a 1997 Paris car crash as she fled paparazzi.
Other claimants are pop star Elton John, his husband David Furnish, the actors Liz Hurley and Sadie Frost, politician Simon Hughes, and Doreen Lawrence, whose son Stephen was killed in a racist murder in 1993.
ANL had "not been able to deliver a 'knockout blow' to the claims of any of these claimants", the judge said in his 95-page ruling.
"In my judgement, each claimant has a real prospect of demonstrating that Associated... concealed from him/her the relevant facts upon which a worthwhile claim of unlawful information gathering could have been advanced," he wrote.
Harry and the other claimants accuse ANL of methods such as hiring private investigators, tapping phone calls and impersonating individuals to obtain medical information for articles. 
The court has been told the alleged wrongdoing dates back to 1993 and continued to as late as 2018.
ANL has dismissed the allegations, arguing the case should not go to trial.
Harry, 39, and his wife Meghan, 42, quit royal duties in 2020 and relocated to California, in part blaming media attention for the move.
The prince, who is formally known as the Duke of Sussex and is the younger son of King Charles III, has vowed to make reforming the British media his life's mission.
The case is one of a number legal battles he is waging with different UK newspapers over privacy concerns.
Â© Agence France-Presse
articles.title: Prince Harry wins latest round in legal battle with UK newspapers

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
When Han Jiali's beloved cat Dabai was taken from her Shanghai home last year, she embarked on a hunt for her pet that took her deep into the bowels of China's underground feline meat trade.
Most people in China do not eat cat meat, but an estimated four million furry friends are slaughtered for food each year in an illegal market that includes areas of Guangdong province, neighbouring Guangxi and beyond, according to Humane Society International.
Han, who has spent thousands of dollars and weeks at a time tracking cat meat traders through China, has uncovered a supply chain preying on urban strays and outdoor pets in the region surrounding Shanghai.
Her quest to find Dabai led her to grimy processing plants in Guangdong, where she saw skinned cat carcasses piled in crates and sacks of furâ¦
articles.title: China's animal lovers fight illegal cat meat trade

Colin Deveraux, whoâs in his mid-60s, was walking toward a river in northern Australia to take care of some fencing when he saw fish clustering in a billabong, a pond left behind when the river changes course or flood waters ebb. Realizing there was something else in the water besides the fish, he abandoned his idea of catching some and turned to leave. âThe water had receded, and it was down to this dirty water in the middle,â Deveraux told Australian broadc...
articles.title: Australian cattleman attacked by crocodile bites back and lives

Karhi published an open letter on Thursday expressing his âdeep concern regarding recent reports about (the outletsâ) employeeâs alleged involvement in the tragic event in southern Israelâ early last month when more than 1,400 were killed. The letter, addressed to the AP, Reuters, the New Yor...
articles.title: News organizations deny photojournalists had prior knowledge of Hamas attack

articles.author: Matthew Chapman
articles.description:
House Oversight Committee Chair James Comer (R-KY) is moving ahead with a subpoena against Los Angeles-based real estate investor Elizabeth Hirsch Naftali, who purchased art from Hunter Biden â despite the fact that Naftali is currently dealing with her three-year-old niece being held hostage by Hamas in the Gaza Strip following the 10/7 terrorist attack.
Rep. Dan Goldman (D-NY) is enraged by this, issuing a statement accusing the Republican chairman of abusing his power to harass the family of a terror victim.
"In the clearest sign yet of House Republicans' devious and distorted priorities, Chairman Comer has decided to subpoena a private American citizen whose 3-year-old niece is currently being held hostage in Gaza by the terrorist group Hamas," said Goldman. "Despite no evidence of wrongdoing by President Biden, House Republicans are spending their time attacking the grieving family of a Hamas hostage rather than working to get that hostage released."
"Chairman Comer's behavior is disgusting," continued Goldman. "In his soulless desperation to smear President Biden ahead of the 2024 election, he has stooped to an entirely new low of abandoning the American families of hostages in a pathetic attempt to score political points against President Biden. In this trying time at home and around the world, the American people cannot tolerate this wild goose chase anymore. It must stop immediately."
Comer has spent months trying to look for solid evidence that the president has been laundering bribes through his son's international business deals. No such evidence has yet emerged, and many of their hearings with Hunter Biden's business associates have if anything provided evidence of the opposite.
The investigation has been folded into a broader impeachment inquiry into the president, which as of now has not actually formulated a theory of charges against him.
articles.title: 'Soulless': James Comer slammed for subpoenaing family of 3-year-old Hamas hostage

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
Among the claims made in Wednesday's debate came from Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R), who touted his quick action in defense of Israel. 
"I already acted in Florida," DeSantis claimed. "We deactivated them. We're not going to use state tax dollars to fund jihad. No way. And what is Biden doing?"
DeSantis was talking about pro-Hamas student groups in the state. But it turns out it was a lie, according to his own appointee, who sought to expose him for it, reported The Tallahassee Democrat. 
Ray Rodrigues, DeSantis' appointee to chancellor of the State University System of Florida, told the paper that the universities found proof that the groups weren't "subservient or under" that national organization when they investigated the constitutions of the two chapters of the National Students for Jâ¦
articles.title: Ron DeSantis' own higher education appointee says he lied in debate

articles.author: Kathleen Culliton
articles.description:
A Texas lawmaker's office was repeatedly vandalized this week with messages criticizing the congress member's position on the Israel-Hamas war. 
U.S. Rep. Monica De La Cruz said on Thursday police are investigating what she described in a press release as pro-Hamas messages scrawled on her District 15 office in McAllen, Texas.
The vandals wrote on her door, entryway, and sheets left outside the office, "Monica murders," "Israel kills Jews too," "Israel is doing genocide and you support it," and "You can't escape your crimes Monica." 
De La Cruz believes she was targeted because her South Texas district has a "small but vibrant Jewish community," of which she counts herself as an ally, she said. 
"My support for Israel and the Jewish community is, always has been, and always will be unwavering," De La Cruz said. "I make no apologies for standing firmly against anti-Semitism. These vandals will not intimidate or silence me."
The war in Israel and Gaza, spurred by a surprise Hamas attack last month, has already claimed the lives of thousands, including numerous civilians killed on the Oct. 7 attack. 
On Thursday, the White House announced that Israel has agreed to four-hour daily humanitarian pauses in the fighting.
articles.title: Republican lawmaker says her office was vandalized over Israel support

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
France accused Russia Thursday of interfering in its affairs by sharing photos online of Stars of David found daubed on dozens of buildings in Paris.
The foreign ministry in a statement accused the Russian RRN/Doppelganger network of attempting to "exploit international crises to sow confusion and create tension in the public debate in France and Europe", and of mounting a "new operation of Russian online interference".
The accusation came after French prosecutors this week launched an investigation into the possibility that the graffiti, widely condemned as anti-Semitic, may have been carried out at the "express demand" of an individual residing abroad.
An investigating magistrate will probe the intention of the acts, prosecutor Laure Beccuau said in a statement Tuesday, following the arrest of two Moldovans who told investigators they were acting at the behest of a third party.
This has led to widespread suspicion that the French probe is specifically targeting Russia.
Tensions rising in France
On Thursday, Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova told reporters that such accusations were "stupid, utter rubbish and just plain undignified".
"This is an attempt by the authorities in France, or their special services, simply to pretend that the growth of anti-Semitism in France is something other than an internal problem," she added.
The RRN/Doppelganger network has been accused of previous disinformation campaigns against France.
Tensions have been rising in France, home to large Jewish and Muslim communities, in the wake of the unprecedented attack by Palestinian militant group Hamas on Israel on October 7 which has been followed by Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip.
The graffiti, which for some brought back horrific memories of the Nazi occupation of Paris during World War II and the deportation of French Jews to death camps, was condemned across the political spectrum.
(AFP)
articles.title: France accuses Russia of 'online interference' over Stars of David graffiti in Paris

articles.author: Sky Palma
articles.description:
A police officer in Australia was convicted on charges that he pointed a gun at a colleague and warned him not to reveal spoilers from the movie Top Gun: Maverick, Australia's ABC reported. 
Court documents say that back in May, 26-year-old Probationary Constable Morgan Royston told Constable Dominic Francis Gaynor that he saw the movie the previous night, saying, "I'll spoil it for you." Gaynor, 30, then laughed and said: "Don't spoil the movie, c***".
Gaynor also reportedly said, "I'll shoot you."
"He pointed his firearm at the vicinity of the complainant and held it stationary for five seconds," the documents say. "The offender's finger was on the receiver and not the trigger. The offender was laughing throughout this incident."
Gaynor ultimately pleaded guilty to "carrying a firearm with disregard for the complainant's safety."
"This is a case where the skylarking and tomfoolery in an employment context has gone awry," Gaynor's counsel Chris Micali told the court.
"This is going to cost him dearly."
Read the full report at The ABC.
articles.title: Cop charged for pointing gun at colleague who threatened to give up 'Top Gun' spoilers

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Biden has been pressing Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for longer breaks in the fighting after more than a month of war sparked by the October 7 attacks by Hamas.
Israeli troops and Hamas are now locked in heavy, close-quarters fighting in Gaza City in the north of the Gaza Strip.
"Israel will begin to implement four-hour pauses in areas of northern Gaza each day, with an announcement to be made three hours beforehand," National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters.
"We've been told by the Israelis that there will be no military operations in these areas over the duration of the pause (and) that this process is starting today."
Fighting has raged since gunmen from the Islamist group Hamas poured over the Gaza border with Israel and, according to Israeli officialsâ¦
articles.title: Israel agrees to four-hour 'pauses' in Gaza, U.S. says

articles.description: Palestinian supporters marched peacefully through central London on Saturday, even as right-wing counter-protesters clashed with police, after a week of angry debate over whether to permit the demonstration on a day when Britain honored its war dead.
articles.title: London police clash with counter-protesters as tensions rise over a pro-Palestinian peace march

Reuters: Moody's turns negative on US credit rating, draws Washington ireÂ 
NEW YORK/WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Moody's on Friday lowered its outlook on the U.S. credit rating to "negative" from "stable" citing large fiscal deficits and a decline in debt affordability, a move that drew immediate criticism from President Joe Biden's administration.Â 
The move follows a rating downgrade of the sovereign by another ratings agency, Fitch, this year, which came after months of political brinkmanship around the U.S. debt ceiling.

Federal spending and political polarization have been a rising concern for investors, contributing to a selloff that took U.S. government bond prices to their lowest levels in 16 years. 

Â

BRUSSELS (Reuters) - A European Union plan to spend up to 20 billion euros ($21.4 billion) on military aid for Ukraine is meeting resistance from EU countries and may not survive in its current form, diplomats say.Â 
Josep Borrell, the EU's foreign policy chief, proposed in July that the bloc create a fund with up to 5 billion euros a year over four years as part of broader Western security commitments to bolster Ukraine as it fights Russia's invasion.Â 
But as EU defence ministers prepare to discuss the plan in Brussels on Tuesday, diplomats say multiple countries - including EU heavyweight Germany - have voiced reservations about committing such large sums years in advance.Â

The new left-populist government of Slovakia, a country neighboring Ukraine that had been one of its staunchest supporters, on Wednesday rejected a proposed package of military aid for Kyiv, fulfilling a campaign promise by Prime Minister Robert Fico to halt assistance in the war against Russia.Â

Still, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergey Ryabkov stressed that Moscow did not plan to initiate the severance of diplomatic ties with WashingtonÂ 
MOSCOW, November 9. /TASS/. Washingtonâs behavior may compel Moscow to downgrade diplomatic relations or even cut ties, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergey Ryabkov said.Â 
"We are indeed going through an acute crisis in relations, the likes of which we have never seen before. MOSCOW (Reuters) -Nikolai Patrushev, a powerful ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin, said on Wednesday that the "destructive" policies of the United States and its allies were increasing the risk that nuclear, chemical or biological weapons would be used.Â 
Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 has led to the most serious confrontation between Moscow and the West since the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, and the post-Cold War arms control architecture has crumbled.Â 
The West says the war in Ukraine is a Russian imperial-style land grab. The Kremlin says the conflict is part of a broader struggle with a declining West which it accuses of sowing chaos around the world to try to maintain its dominance.Â 
Patrushev said the post-Cold War order, including the dominance of the United States, was waning.

Business Insider: US government debt is on track to surpass $50 trillion by 2033. That means $5.2 billion is piling up every day. 

Â 
The US government's debt is on track to surpass $50 trillion by 2033, Bank of America said in a Tuesday note, citing data from the Congressional Budget Office.Â 
* The US government's public outstanding debt is on track to surpass $50 trillion by 2033.Â 
* The increase comes out to roughly $5.2 billion every day or $218 million every hour, Bank of America estimated.Â 
* "Central banks may simply bail out governments in coming years via QE," BofA said.Â 
US public debt outstanding currently sits at $33.6 trillion and is expected to surge by $20 trillion to $54 trillion within the next decade amid "fiscal excess in the 2020s," Bank of America investment strategist Michael Hartnett said.
"US public debt is... more than the combined GDPs of China, Japan, Germany, and India," he wrote, adding that the outstanding debt is set to surge by $5.2 billion every single day, or $218 million every hour, for the next 10 years.

Â 
Read more ....
